title: Particle Motion in the XY-Plane
driving_question: How can we use algebra and geometry to model and analyze the motion of a particle in the xy-plane?
short_background_context: In this mission, we will explore the motion of a particle in the xy-plane. The particle's position at any time t ≥ 0 is given by the coordinates (x(t), y(t)), and its velocity vector is (2te^(-t), sin(t^1.25)). At time t=0, the particle is at position (-2, 5). We will use algebraic and geometric concepts to find the speed and acceleration of the particle at a specific time, calculate the total distance traveled by the particle over a given interval, and determine the coordinates of the point where the particle is farthest to the left.
tasks: Find the speed of the particle at time t=1.2 and the acceleration vector of the particle at the same time.
Calculate the total distance traveled by the particle over the time interval 0 ≤ t ≤ 1.2.
Determine the coordinates of the point at which the particle is farthest to the left for t ≥ 0. Explain why there is no point at which the particle is farthest to the right for t ≥ 0.
pre_thinking_prompts: What do you know about velocity and acceleration?
How can you calculate the total distance traveled by a particle given its velocity?
What does it mean for a particle to be 'farthest to the left'?
reflection_prompt: What did you learn about the motion of a particle in the xy-plane? How did algebra and geometry help you analyze this motion?
ai_tutor_prompts: Can you explain how you found the speed of the particle at t=1.2?
Why did you choose this method to calculate the total distance traveled?
What makes you think the particle is farthest to the left at this point?
remix_zone: Try changing the velocity vector and initial position of the particle. How do these changes affect the particle's motion?
